qas.question: How were humanist able to identify the development of humanist thought?
What was included in this quest for knowledge of the belief system?
If your were unsure of the authenticity of an ancient text how could you verify it?
What caused a large migration of Greek refuges in the 1450s?
How were humanist able to ruin the development of humanist thought?
What was missing in this quest for knowledge of the belief system?
What helps to discredit the authenticity of an ancient text?
What caused a small migration of Greek refuges in the 1550s?

context: The humanists' close study of <a0_0><b4_0>Latin literary texts<b4_0/><a0_0/> soon enabled them to discern historical differences in the writing styles of different periods. By analogy with what they saw as decline of Latin, they applied the principle of ad fontes, or back to the sources, across broad areas of learning, seeking out manuscripts of <a1_0><b5_0>Patristic literature<b5_0/><a1_0/> as well as pagan authors. In 1439, while employed in Naples at the court of Alfonso V of Aragon (at the time engaged in a dispute with the Papal States) the humanist Lorenzo Valla used stylistic textual analysis, now called <a2_0>philology<a2_0/>, to prove that the Donation of Constantine, which purported to confer temporal powers on the Pope of Rome, was an 8th-century forgery. For the next 70 years, however, neither Valla nor any of his contemporaries thought to apply the techniques of <b6_0>philology<b6_0/> to other controversial manuscripts in this way. Instead, after the fall of the <b7_0>Byzantine Empire<b7_0/> to the Turks in 1453, which brought a flood of Greek Orthodox refugees to Italy, humanist scholars increasingly turned to the study of Neoplatonism and Hermeticism, hoping to bridge the differences between the Greek and Roman Churches, and even between Christianity itself and the non-Christian world. The refugees brought with them <a3_0>Greek manuscripts<a3_0/>, not only of Plato and Aristotle, but also of the Christian Gospels, previously unavailable in the Latin West.
